Award.AwardTitle: MRI-R2: Development of Magneto-Optics Kerr Effect for in-situ dynamic studies of film growth
Award.AbstractNarration:
Technical Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Magneto-optics Kerr effect (MOKE) for in-situ dynamic studies is an indispensable tool to probe size effects, surfaces, and interfaces of thin films and multi-layers during deposition by magnetron sputtering. This project aims to develop an instrument that will provide the capability to grow and characterize materials under controlled environment which is ideal to gain critical and fundamental understanding of optical, electronic, and magnetic properties of multifunctional materials, multiferroic materials, and filled carbon nanotubes. The proposed instrument will be developed and operated out of the Department of Physics at Morgan State University. This instrument will be used to enhance outreach programs to assure the maximum opportunity for training and research by minority students. The Unique aspect of this proposal is samples of interest prepared and studied with MOKE in-situ and ex-situ will further be studied using advanced x-ray techniques such as x-ray magnetic circular dichroism and x-ray element mapping spectrometry at the National Synchrotron Light Source of the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

Layman Summary:
This award is funded under the American Recovery and Reinvestment Act of 2009 (Public Law 111-5).

Magneto-optics Kerr effect (MOKE) used in preparation chamber of materials is an indispensable tool in controlling the magnetic properties of materials that are useful to advance technology such as ultra high-density data storage for next generation personal computers and in developing fast, miniaturized, and reliable electronic devices. This project aims to develop an instrument that will provide capability to grow and characterize materials under controlled environment which is ideal to gain critical and fundamental understanding of optical, electronic, and magnetic properties of materials useful in all areas of science and technology. The proposed instrument will be developed and operated out of the Department of Physics at Morgan State University. This instrument will be used to enhance outreach programs to assure the maximum opportunity for training and research by minority students. The Unique aspect of this proposal is materials of interest prepared and studied with MOKE in-situ and ex-situ will further be studied using advanced x-ray techniques at the National Synchrotron Light Source of the Brookhaven National Laboratory.

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: Normal 0 false false false EN-US X-NONE X-NONE Magneto-Optic Kerr effect (MOKE) instrument was built by the PI, Dereje Seifu (Morgan State University), at his research laboratory in Morgan State University and was used to study Fe thin films 50 nm thick, 1 nm (nanometer) is a billionth of a meter, and multi-layered thin films synthesized using DC magnetron sputtering system all acquired through NSF Major Research Instrumentation grant. The magnetron sputtering system has three DC sources one of the sources was upgraded to a dual DC/RF source with an additional funding from the Army Research Laboratory through a Cooperative Research Agreement (CRA). The magnetron sputtering system has two ports available for future upgrades to install atomic-layer deposition and an e-beam sputtering systems useful for more advanced material synthesis. The three source guns and the two turbo pumps for the processing chamber and the load lock are water cooled by a stand-alone chiller. The processing chamber vacuum can reach up to a pressure of 10-8 Torr, 1 Torr is 1/760 of a standard atmosphere, and the load lock serves to exchange samples without breaking vacuum which is energy efficient and time saver. Fe thin films of thickness 50 nm were prepared on MgO (100) substrate at several temperatures capped with 5 nm Cu to avoid oxidation. These samples were studied using MOKE and other magnetic characterization tools. This study on nano-metric films revealed the dependence of magneto-crystalline anisotropy on deposition temperatures. This study is useful since nano-metric thin films, few atomic mono-layers thick, can exhibit an out-of-plane uniaxial surface anisotropy which is sufficient to overcome the demagnetizing field. This feature is very useful for magnetic recording since data can be recorded at higher densities in such magnetic media. Using the RF source a tri-layered thin film sandwiching a thin insulator layer about 5 nm thick between two conductors was synthesized, Fe/MgO/Fe on MgO (100), this system is known as magnetic tunnel junction (MTJ) with conductivity that is highly dependent on an externally applied magnetic field. MTJ has several technological applications including magnetic random access memory (MRAM) and magnetic sensor. These magnetic materials were also used to fill carbon nanotubes that are vertically grown and substrate supported using magnetron sputtering system. In conclusion the NSF-MRI-R2 funding has established state of the art infrastructure at Morgan State University to further study lower-dimensional solid state structures such as thin films and magnetic materials filled carbon nano-tubes materials with novel optical, electronic, and magnetic characteristics governed by quantum mechanics. Understanding these structures is extremely important in order to probe size effects, surface and interface physics, to gain critical understanding of the physics of lower dimensional materials as well as to develop new technologies since the quest to develop new technologies is at the heart of material research. This effort was accomplished to a considerable part by undergraduate research students supported by Morgan State University LSAMP grant over the summer. Students who worked on this project presented their work at the Science symposium at Morgan State University. The first students to work on this project were two Electrical Engineering majors who joined the work force after graduation. They presented their work on "Fe thin films characterized by MOKE" at the 2011 Science symposium at Morgan State University and one of the two students used this work for his senior project.
